title: How to Put on a Wetsuit

steps.title: Put protective gear on.
steps.content: Put protective gear on. If desired, put on your protective gear now. This often includes a rashguard or rash suit usually made of Lycra. Of course, some people prefer to only wear their bathing suits, or even nothing at all.

steps.title: Unzip the wetsuit..
steps.content: Unzip the wetsuit.. You'll want to make sure that the suit is fully unzipped. With most wetsuits, the zipper will go in the back. [1] X Research source If there are any hitches or kinks in the zipper, work them out now.

steps.title: Start with your feet and legs.
steps.content: Start with your feet and legs. Once you have the wetsuit lined up, pull your wetsuit over your foot and ankle, gradually working it up over the knee one leg at a time. [2] X Research source Make sure that any wetsuit padding is properly aligned. [3] X Research source There shouldn't be any large wrinkles or folds. [4] X Research source Once the wetsuit is up around mid thigh, switch to the other leg. If either you or the wetsuit is wet and you have difficulty pulling it on, consider using plastic bags or socks on your feet. This can make it easier. [5] X Research source You can also use conditioner or vegetable oil as a lubricant. Work out rolls and ripples in the wetsuit as you move up your legs.

steps.title: Pull over your hips and torso next.
steps.content: Pull over your hips and torso next. Once the suit is past mid thigh on both legs, gently pull the suit past your hips until the seam is nestled snugly in your crotch. [6] X Research source Now pull the suit up over your torso and onto your shoulders. Your crotch shouldn't be pinched, but you shouldn't have any loose fabric or pockets either. It should feel like a firm second skin. You can jump up and down to make sure that the fit is right. [7] X Research source Loose pockets will circulate cold water, ruining the purpose of the wetsuit. [8] X Research source The wetsuit shouldn't overly constrict movement either. If it feels too tight or like you can't move, take it off and get a bigger size before you waste more time.

steps.title: Insert one arm at a time.
steps.content: Insert one arm at a time. Use the same method that you did with your legs. Be careful with fingernails on the fabric. [9] X Research source Gently pull the suit up your arms and then lift it onto your chest. Just like it was with your crotch, you'll want the wetsuit to be snug and tight without constricting movement. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Seal the deal.
steps.content: Seal the deal. If you have a rear-zip wetsuit, have a friend help you zip up. [11] X Research source Reaching and trying to zip it yourself can put strain on both the zipper and suit.

steps.title: Lock it up.
steps.content: Lock it up. Your suit should have hook-and-loop fastener fastenings over the zipper and at the neck area. Close these fastenings to prevent the zipper from unzipping and make your suit more watertight. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Check the fit.
steps.content: Check the fit. Walk around, raise your knees, rotate your shoulders, bend your arms, and maybe do a few jumps or squats. [13] X Research source While you should be able to feel the snugness of the wetsuit, your movement shouldn't be overly constricted. You shouldn't have any big pockets or loose areas either. [14] X Research source If your movement is constricted, take the suit off and get a bigger one. If you have large pockets or loose areas, take the suit off and get a smaller one.

steps.title: Finish up.
steps.content: Finish up. Now that the suit is on and you have confirmed that it is properly sized, you can put your hood on if you are going to be using one. Congrats. Enjoy the water!

steps.title: Unzip.
steps.content: Unzip. If you were wearing a hood, remove it. Leave it inside out. Have a friend or partner unzip your wetsuit fully if it is a rear-zip wetsuit.

steps.title: Remove the wetsuit from your neck and shoulders.
steps.content: Remove the wetsuit from your neck and shoulders. Peel the wetsuit off of your neck and down your shoulders. [15] X Research source To get it off of your shoulders it helps to slide a thumb between your shoulder and the wetsuit. [16] X Research source

steps.title: Slide out your arms.
steps.content: Slide out your arms. One at a time, remove your arms from the wetsuit. Be sure to use your fingertips rather than fingernails. [17] X Research source Pull each arm fully out of its sleeve, leaving the arms inside out.

steps.title: Pull it down your torso and hips.
steps.content: Pull it down your torso and hips. Peel the suit down your torso like a banana. [18] X Research source Then you'll want to pull it past your hips in a single motion. [19] X Research source Wiggle if you need to in order to get the wetsuit past your buttocks and out of your crotch.

steps.title: Remove your legs.
steps.content: Remove your legs. Roll the wetsuit down your legs. [20] X Research source When you get to your ankles, put a hand inside of the wetsuit at the ankle and use it to hold the wetsuit leg open while you slide your foot out. [21] X Research source Repeat with the other foot when you are done. Fortunately, taking off a wet wetsuit is far easier than putting one on! Leave the wetsuit inside out so that it can get some fresh air. Leaving the wetsuit inside out is necessary for proper cleaning... especially since a fair amount of the time, you might end up peeing inside your wetsuit. Peeing inside your wetsuit is fairly normal. Not only are you stuck in it for a long time, but the pee can make the wetsuit a lot warmer.

steps.title: Clean the wetsuit.
steps.content: Clean the wetsuit. Be sure to rinse the wetsuit down with cold, fresh water. Let the wetsuit hang dry. Never use heat or an automatic dryer to dry it. [22] X Research source Heat can cause the rubber of the wetsuit to become brittle. Be sure to clean the wetsuit thoroughly, especially on the inside!
